questions.text: What is the most common gene mutation associated with hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
The most common mutation seen in hemochromatosis is a cysteine to tyrosine substitution at position 282 (C282Y) in the HFE gene.

HFE mutations are the most common cause of hereditary hemochromatosis and are inherited as an autosomal recessive trait.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop iron overload?
questions.solution:
Thalassemia minor does not result in iron overload. Secondary hemochromatosis or iron overload is characterized by the deposition of iron in parenchymal cells.

Related Pearl: Classification of Iron Overload

 Primary / Hereditary Hemochromatosis

HFE gene-related

  • Type 1: C282Y mutations of genes encoding HFE 

Non-HFE gene-related

  • Type 2: Juvenile hemochromatosis
    • 2a - HJV mutation (hemojuvelin)
    • 2b - HAMP mutation (Hepcidin)
  • Type 3: Transferrin receptor 2 (TfR2) related 
  • Type 4: Ferroportin-related HH 

Secondary / Acquired Hemochromatosis

Transfusion iron overload

  • Thalassemia major
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Chronic hemolytic anemias

Chronic liver disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Miscellaneous

  • Congenital atransferrinemia
  • African iron overload (Bantu siderosis)

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical manifestations of hemochromatosis is incorrectly matched with its mechanism of onset?
  Clinical feature Mechanism
1.  Hypothyroidism -  Iron deposition in pituitary
2.  Arthropathy -  Deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals
3.  Skin hyperpigmentation -  Increased melanin production
4.  Sexual dysfunction -  Iron deposition in testes
questions.solution:
Sexual dysfunction (decreased libido, impotence, amenorrhea) in hemochromatosis occurs as a result of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This is due to iron deposition in the pituitary gland, not testes.

Iron deposition occurs in the following sites:  

Organ Manifestation
Liver Hepatomegaly
Skin

Slate-grey or bronze skin hyperpigmentation: increased melanin synthesis due to iron deposition
Pancreas pancreatic diabetes/type 3C diabetes
Pituitary

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Secondary hypothyroidism
Heart

Dilated cardiomyopathy

Congestive heart failure

Arrhythmias
Joints

Arthropathy is due to:

  • Iron deposition
  • Calcium pyrophosphate deposition (pseudogout)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy undergoes genetic testing as his brother has been diagnosed with hereditary hemochromatosis. He is found to be homozygous for the C282Y mutation. Which of the following is the strongest indicator that he will develop symptoms of the disease?
questions.solution:
Serum ferritin > 1000 μg/L is the strongest predictor of disease expression among individuals homozygous for the C282Y mutation. 

Many patients with C282Y mutations are initially asymptomatic and do not show features of iron overload. In such patients, serum ferritin can indicate whether they are likely to develop the disease as ferritin levels reflect the total iron stores. 

As ferritin levels may be high following inflammatory conditions, combined measurement of ferritin and transferrin saturation is done in a practical setting to avoid false positives. It is also repeated once inflammation subsides. If these tests are abnormal, genetic testing for HFE mutations is done.

questions.text: A 47-year-old diabetic man is worried as the skin over his face, neck, and dorsum of hands has turned greyish over the past two months. He also complains of abdominal and joint pain. On examination, gynecomastia and hepatomegaly are noted. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. The treatment of choice is the removal of excess iron by phlebotomy.

Phlebotomy is an inexpensive, convenient, and safe method of treatment. In this process, 500 mL of blood is removed 1-2 times weekly which removes 200-250 mg of iron. Weekly phlebotomy should be continued until the serum ferritin level is ≤100 μg/L and every 3 months thereafter. It is contraindicated in severe anemia and hypoproteinemia.

Chelating agents bind to iron to form complexes that get excreted and are the drugs of choice. Drugs such as deferoxamine and deferasirox are commonly used. However, they are less effective and more expensive than phlebotomy.

Liver transplantation is indicated either in end-stage liver disease or in refractory cases.

Supportive management includes avoiding iron-containing substances such as red meat, multi-vitamin tablets, etc. Alcohol should be completely avoided as it can aggravate the disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with hereditary hemochromatosis has been started on weekly phlebotomy. All of the following features will improve with this treatment except:
questions.solution: In hemochromatosis, removal of excess iron through phlebotomy has no effect on arthropathy and hypogonadism.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Wilson's disease?

choices.text: AP1S1 gene is essential for normal functioning
Siblings of affected children have 1 in 4 risk of the disease

questions.solution:
Wilson’s disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene on Chr.13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions:

  • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin
  • Helps excrete free copper in bile.

Thus, an ATP7B deficiency leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues. It is an autosomal recessive condition. So, siblings of affected children have a 1 in 4 chance.

Intracellular trafficking of ATP7B (Wilson's disease) and ATP7A (Menke's disease) genes are regulated by an adaptor protein encoded by the AP1S1 gene. Mutations in this gene result in a syndrome with features of both Wilson's and Menke's diseases. It is called MEDNIK syndrome:

  • Mental retardation
  • Enteropathy
  • Deafness
  • Neuropathy
  • Ichthyosis
  • Keratodermia.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding KF ring?
  1. Seen in all patients with neurological involvement
  2. Is seen only for Wilson's disease
  3. Resolves with desferrioxamine
  4. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement
  5. Seen in superior and inferior pole of Descemet's membrane
questions.solution:
Among the given options only statements 1 and 5 are true.

Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings are seen in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological involvement. It initially appears as a crescent in the superior pole of Descemet's membrane and gradually extends inferiorly, eventually becoming circumferential in shape.

KF rings occur due to copper deposition in the descemet's membrane. It is golden-brown to greenish-brown in color and can be best seen by slit-lamp examination.

The image below shows a KF ring : 

While it is a characteristic sign of Wilson’s disease (statement 2), it can also be seen in: 

  • Primary biliary cholangitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Cholestasis

KF rings are present in almost 95% of patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms compared to around 65% of those with hepatic presentations (statement 4).

They disappear on treatment with copper-chelating agents like d-penicillamine (while desferrioxamine is an iron chelating agent) and reappear with disease progression (statement 3).

questions.text: In patients with Wilson's disease, Kayser-Fleischer rings are most commonly associated with:
questions.solution:
The presence of the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring in Wilson's disease is most commonly associated with neuropsychiatric manifestations such as dystonia.

In majority of the cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is due to the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia (leading to bilateral degeneration and atrophy) and cortex. The features include:

  • Dysarthria (most common): Irregular word spacing, hypophonic or spastic speech
  • Dystonia: Vacuous smile i.e mask-like face with an open mouth
  • Parkinsonism: Bradykinesia, postural instability, rigidity
  • Subcortical dementia: Slow mental processing, memory loss
  • Psychiatric symptoms: Loss of emotional control, depression, hyperactivity
  • Decreased scholastic performance: Deterioration in handwriting, clumsiness
  • Autonomic symptoms: Excessive sweating and salivation, sexual dysfunction
  • Wing beating tremors (seen in advanced disease): High amplitude tremor that is prominent with arms abducted, elbows flexed and palms facing downward.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman is being evaluated in the emergency department for a 3-day history of dark-colored urine and abdominal distension. On examination, she is conscious and oriented. Icterus is present. The following investigations are done. Which of the following would you suspect?
Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dl
Hematocrit 26%
Reticulocytes 5%
Platelets 1.3 x 105/mm3
Serum total iron Reduced
Serum ferritin Normal
Serum ALT 110 IU/L
Serum AST 240 IU/L
Serum ALP 30 IU/L
Total bilirubin 13 mg/dl
Anti-Hbs IgG Positive
USG Abdomen Nodular liver and enlarged spleen
questions.solution:
The given laboratory values indicate hepatic disease and hemolytic anemia (low Hb with high reticulocyte count). These lab findings along with clinical features point to a diagnosis of Wilson's disease.

The clinical features of Wilson’s disease include:

System Clinical features
Hepatic
(most common)

Jaundice
Abdominal pain
Hepatomegaly
Fatigue
Ascites
Variceal bleed
Coagulation defects

High AST & ALT with low ALP
Neurological Dysarthria
Dystonia
Parkinsonism
Subcortical dementia
Depression
Wing beating tremors
Decreased scholastic performance
Ophthalmic Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings
Sunflower cataract
Others Hemolytic anemia (Coombs negative)
Acute pancreatitis
Fanconi's syndrome
Hyperparathyroidism
Cardiomyopathy
Spontaneous abortions
Infertility

Option A: Hemochromatosis presents with clinical features of iron overload. Serum ferritin and total iron are elevated.

Option B: Acute viral hepatitis presents with positive HbsAg, whereas anti-Hbs IgG indicates past infection. There is tender hepatomegaly with very high levels of transaminases (>1000 IU/L).

Option C: Primary biliary cirrhosis presents with jaundice, severe itching, and pale stools. There are high levels of direct bilirubin, ALP, and positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hepatitis, progressive neurological degeneration, and the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring seen in the image are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The initial step regarding investigations done for the diagnosis is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels.

Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring is a golden to greenish-brown ring of deposition of copper in the Descemets membrane of the peripheral cornea. Patients with neurological manifestations manifest with KF ring in >95% of cases.

Lab investigations in Wilson's disease would show:

Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑  (>100 μg/24h)  Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

The gold standard technique for diagnosis of Wilson’s disease is percutaneous needle liver biopsy for measurement of hepatic copper levels >200 μg/g of dry weight.

Option B: The role of total serum copper in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease is limited. Measurement of serum ceruloplasmin and urinary copper is preferred.

Option C: ATP7B enzyme assays have shown promise in early studies as a neonatal screening test for Wilson's disease. However, it is not yet part of routine clinical practice.

Option D: Karyotyping is done for every asymptomatic 1st and 2nd degree relative of a patient with Wilson’s disease. This helps differentiate the carriers (heterozygous) from the patients (homozygous) and can lead to early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings would be seen in a patient with Wilson's disease?
  1. Decreased total serum copper
  2. Increased total serum copper
  3. Decreased serum ceruloplasmin
  4. Increased urinary copper
  5. Decreased free serum copper
questions.solution:
The following findings will be seen in a patient with Wilson's disease:

  • Decreased total serum copper
  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin
  • Increased urinary copper
Lab markers Change in Wilson's disease Reason
Serum ceruloplasmin ↓↓↓ ATP7B deficiency results in reduced bound copper
24h urinary copper ↑↑ Excess free copper excreted in urine
Total serum copper ↓ Due to marked reduction in ceruloplasmin

Normally, >90% of copper exists in bound form and <10% in free form. In Wilson’s disease, despite elevated levels of free copper, the marked reduction in ceruloplasmin results in a net reduction of total serum copper i.e.,

↓total serum copper =↑free copper + ↓↓ceruloplasmin

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abnormal posture. His scholastic performance used to be above average but has deteriorated over the last 3 months. Dystonia and increased muscle tone are noted on clinical examination. The following picture is seen on ophthalmic examination. What is the gold standard for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring with sunflower cataract are suggestive of Wilson's disease. The gold standard for diagnosis is the estimation of liver copper following biopsy.

A copper level of >200 μg/g dry liver tissue is diagnostic for Wilson's disease. It is measured using neutron activation analysis or atomic absorption spectrometry. 

Sunflower cataract is a rare finding of Wilson’s disease. It occurs due to the deposition of copper in the center of the lens.

questions.text: A pathologist is preparing a tissue sample from the liver biopsy of a patient with Wilson's disease. What stain will he use?
questions.solution:
In Wilson’s disease, liver biopsy samples are stained using rubeanic acid to visualize the cytoplasmic copper. 

Another stain used for copper is the rhodanine stain. However, copper staining is not reliable for diagnosis and a quantitative copper assay must be performed.

The given image shows the staining of copper by rubeanic acid.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was brought with involuntary, writhing movements of her limbs. On examination, she is anicteric with dystonia and hyperreflexia. Investigations revealed mildly elevated transaminases and low serum ceruloplasmin levels. Which of the following is the safest drug that can be initiated for this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Wilson's disease with predominantly neurological features. The safest drug that can be initiated for this patient is trientine. This is because D-penicillamine can worsen neurological symptoms and would not be tolerated by this patient.

The copper chelating agents, D-penicillamine and trientine are the first-line drugs in the management of Wilson's disease. D-penicillamine is the recommended drug due to its availability and cost-effectiveness compared to trientine.

However, D-penicillamine can precipitate various adverse effects including aplastic anemia, myasthenia gravis and membranous nephropathy. It can also worsen neurological symptoms. Hence, trientine is administered in those who cannot tolerate D-penicillamine.

Elemental zinc is commonly used as a maintenance therapy along with chelating agents. It can also be used as first-line therapy in pregnancy.

Tetrathiomolybdate is currently under phase 2 clinical trials. It has been identified to be effective in patients with neuropsychiatric manifestations but is not approved for clinical use.

Liver transplantation is the definitive treatment for advanced liver disease.

questions.text: For a patient with Wilson's disease, you would administer pyridoxine along with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution: Penicillamine should always be co-administered with pyridoxine (25 mg/day) as it is an antagonist to pyridoxine.

questions.text: The Nazer’s prognostic index for Wilson’s disease includes all of the following parameters except:
questions.solution:
ALT is not a part of Nazer’s prognostic index. 

Nazer’s prognostic index is used to establish disease severity in Wilson’s disease patients who present with hepatic decompensation.

Related Pearl: Nazer’s Prognostic Index

Nazer’s prognostic index for Wilson’s disease

  • Serum bilirubin
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
  • Prolongation of prothrombin time (sec)

Interpretation of Scores :

  • < 7 – Medical therapy
  • 7–9 – Clinical judgement, Either medical / surgical treatment
  • > 9 – Liver transplantation

questions.text: Low serum copper levels attributed to ATP7A gene is due to:
questions.solution:
Low serum copper level attributed to the ATP7A gene is due to Menke's disease (Option C).

Menke's disease or Menke-Kinky hair syndrome is an X-linked recessive condition occurring due to a mutation in the ATP7A gene on chromosome X. This causes impaired transport of dietary copper from the small intestine to the liver leading to low levels of copper-containing enzymes. It presents within 3 years of age and is characterized by:

  • Depigmented kinky hair
  • Failure to thrive
  • Neurodegenerative symptoms like loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, epilepsyLoose, wrinkled skin
  • Multiple fractures
  • Poor visual acuity
  • Recurrent infections.

Lab investigations show low serum copper (<65 μg/dL) and low ceruloplasmin(<20 mg/dl). The disease is fatal as it has no curative treatment. But, administration of L-histidine and copper chloride injections may be beneficial, if started early.

Aceruloplasminemia is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by tissue iron overload, mental deterioration, microcytic anemia, and low serum iron and copper concentrations.

Option B: Low serum copper and low ceruloplasmin is also seen in Wilson’s disease, but is associated with the gene defect ATP7B on chromosome 13. It is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism with features of hepatolenticular degeneration and Kayser Fleischer ring.   

Option A: Dubin Johnson Syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired canalicular excretion of bilirubin due to mutation in MRP-2 protein leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Gilbert’s Syndrome is characterized by decreased UDP glucuronyl transferase activity leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can be autosomal recessive or dominant.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease
